On the field between Borodino and the flèches, beside the wood, the chief action of the day took place on an open space visible from both sides.
The chief action of the day was fought in the simplest and most artless way.
The battle began on both sides with a cannonade from several hundred guns.
When the whole field was covered with smoke, the Campan division advanced from the French right.

The distance to Borodino from the Shevárdino Redoubt was more than a mile as the crow flies.
Napoleon could not see what was happening at Borodino because the distance was more than a mile.

Through the smoke, glimpses of something black, probably men, could be caught.
Through the smoke, glimpses of bayonets could be caught.
From the Shevárdino Redoubt it could not be discovered whether the men were moving or stationary.
From the Shevárdino Redoubt it could not be discovered whether the men were French or Russian.

Napoleon descended the knoll.
Napoleon began walking up and down before the knoll.
